Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis and Directed Assembly of Bio-Hybrid Materials with Membrane-Protein-Mediated Transport Performance
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical:

This award by the Biomaterials Program in the Division of Materials Research to Colorado School of Mines aims to overcome the materials challenge on harnessing membrane protein (MP) functions in engineered systems. MPs represent a family of biologically-derived and bio-renewable high-performance nanomaterials that are largely unexplored. These proteins are the "gate-keepers" of cells, and are involved in critical life processes, such as energy conversion, matter transport and information processing. These same MP-mediated functions are also highly coveted nanoengineering feats in synthetic systems. Exploiting MPs for nanoengineering may help understand, predict, and ultimately control recognition and transport at the nanoscale, but is greatly impeded by the fluidic and labile nature of biomembranes. This study bridges the gap between biotic and abiotic systems by developing chemically versatile synthetic membranes to support MP functions. The successful outcome of this study will help unleash the full potential of MPs to create novel nanotechnologies ranging from solar conversion to high throughput diagnostics. With respect to broad impact on education, this project builds a multi-tiered education program on renewable materials. The objective of this program is to bring societal awareness on sustainability, and motivate undergraduate and K-12 students to pursue career paths on bio-renewable materials. A focused outreach component, "Summer Experience @ Mines", targets minority students at a local high school by hosting their first exposure to engineering studies and college life, and develop curriculum materials for their Biotechnology class. A broader outreach component includes training K-12 science teachers and dissemination of the curriculum materials to local and nearby school districts.


Technical:

This award is to develop bio-hybrid materials with membrane-protein-mediated transport performance. Membrane proteins (MPs) are biologically-derived and bio-renewable high-performance nanomaterials. Despite numerous proof-of-concept demonstrations of MPs' great potential in engineered systems, little is known on how to design synthetic MP-supporting membranes that balance a dichotomy between fluidity and stability, and how to direct spontaneous MP reconstitution into these robust membranes to form 2-dimensional (2-D) or 3-D proteomembrane arrays. Using proteorhodopsin, a light-driven proton pump as a model, this study will elucidate: (1) the directed assembly principles to reconstitute proteorhodopsin into hierarchically organized proteomembrane arrays; and (2) the roles of synthetic membranes in shaping proteorhodopsin function. Since proteorhodopsin has a common seven transmembrane (7 TM) architecture of G protein-coupled receptors, a large family of MPs that regulate energy conversion, matter transport and biosensing. The guiding concepts learnt from this study have the potential to benefit a broad range of MP-based nanotechnologies. This multidisciplinary study provides ample opportunities to train students at the interdisciplinary area of materials engineering, synthetic chemistry, biophysics, and protein engineering. With this award, this research group will design a multi-tiered soft matter education program entitled "Renewable Materials for Sustainable Future". This program aims to: (1) improve educational components on soft matter by course development; (2) support undergraduate students from the Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program, the Society of Women Engineering, and International Exchange Students Program to have "hands-on" research experience; and (3) build regular and systematic outreach activities to K-12 students in local and nearby school districts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthesis and Directed Assembly of Bio-Hybrid Materials with Membrane-Protein-Mediated Transport Performance

The ability to control recognition and transport at the nanoscale holds great promise for technological breakthrough in energy conversion, catalysis and information processing. It is one of the most coveted goals for materials engineering but extremely challenging to reach. Biology answers that same challenge by the development of specialized membrane proteins (MPs) that exquisitely control recognition and transport across the nanometer-thick lipid bilayers through the long history of evolutional experiments. Adapting artificial systems to support MP functions may help understand, predict, and ultimately control matter and energy at the nanoscale; this is particularly enticing in the post-genomic era as recombinant or cell-free expression of many MPs in sizable quantities became feasible. Since Mueller’s exploratory work on reconstituting a cell membrane structure in vitro in the 1960s, great progress has been made on MP reconstitution into different forms of lipid bilayers and fluidic polymersome membranes. However, the labile nature of these membranes limits their use under a broad range of harsh, non-biological conditions. Strengthening methods such as crosslinking, bonding with supporting substrates, encapsulation etc. have been applied to improve membrane stability, but it is desirable to develop synthetic nanomembranes that are sufficiently strong by themselves to support MPs without compromising their structural integrity and functions. Very little is known on how to design these MP-supporting membranes that balance the dichotomy between fluidity and stability, and how to direct spontaneous MP reconstitution into these membranes to form 2-dimensional (2-D) or 3-D proteomembrane arrays. 

The overall objective of this project is to identify the fundamental design principles to direct spontaneous assembly of bio-hybrid materials with MP-mediated transport performance. The central hypothesis is that block copolymer membranes can be designed to direct MP reconstitution spontaneously via a charge-interaction-directed reconstitution (CIDR) mechanism, and the polymer membrane structures can be tuned to support MP functions with durability far superior to that of lipid bilayers. New synthetic strategies have been developed to prepare a series of well-defined block copolymer membranes with systematically varied physicochemical properties. The structure and functions of exemplary MPs from different MP families (i.e. receptor, pump, transporter) have been examined in the model block copolymer membranes. It was found that while the MP-lipid partnership is not exclusive and the "native-like" functions of MPs can be retained in the model block copolymer membranes, the physicochemical properties of the membranes do help regulate individual MP functions. As such, it is possible to balance the dichotomy between fluidity and stability with custom-designed bio-hybrid materials to harness individual MP functions with optimized stability and performance.The molecular interactions driving the formation of proteomembranes were examined and exploited to control the hierarchical organization of proteopolymer membranes at 3D and 2D. A new family of well-defined polymer nanodisc was developed as new platforms to support MP functions, with potential applications for therapeutics. A general “soft-hard” interfacing strategy was developed to unidirectionally assemble 2D planar-supported proteopolymer membrane arrays, which may help create novel nanotechnologies to manage energy conversion, matter transport and high throughput diagnostics.       

Understanding the cooperative assembly between MPs and membranes also cast new light on the development of membrane-active antimicrobials, and the discovery of polymer nanodiscs as a simple and robust nanodisc platform opened new opportunities for nanotechnology development with or without MPs. This multidisciplinary study provided ample opportunities to train a broad range of participants at the interdisciplinary area of materials engineering, chemistry, biophysics, and biology. A total of 6 peer-reviewed publications (2 more in preparation), 22 conference presentations, and 16 trainees (1 postdoc, 1 Ph.D. student, 1 visiting graduate student from India, 1 high school summer intern, 2 MD candidates, and 10 undergraduate students; most from underrepresented groups) were supported by this award. Through the integrated education and outreach activities, this study helped bring broad societal awareness on bio-renewable materials and sustainability, and promoted STEM education at all levels.
